job_title: Procurement and Logistics Officer in New York, NY
pros: The work people do genuinely makes the world a better place, even if sometimes it's mired in senseless bureaucracy due to Columbia and US Gov't policies and structures (funding is mostly USG grant-based). Leadership is generally respectful and considerate. Benefits are above average, especially unlimited sick leave and 25 paid vacation days/year with option of carrying over some unused days into the next fiscal year. Office environment is generally friendly and low-drama. Depending on the job, there are often opportunities for domestic and international travel which are fun and great learning experiences.
cons: Sub-par work-life balance. Leadership people are workaholics and the work expectations trickle down into the rest of the organization. Leadership is stuck in the Compensation is average for the market at best. Office space is crowded and limited (no common dining areas, very small conference rooms, etc.). Resources provided for work such as IT equipment, desk equipment, etc. veer toward the cheap side (asking for a Mac laptop to work on is laughable). Professional growth opportunities are also quite limited due to nature of funding and organization structure. Your best bet for promotion is to have someone vacate a position you desire and are qualified for.

review_title: organizational  change needs to happen ASAP
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Opportunity to work with prominent researchers in the field and within an Ivy League university
-Opportunities for travel (less so during the pandemic of course)
-Decent benefits working for Columbia University, like generous vacation days and good healthcare options
-Salaries are comparable to other NGOs, so not bad
-The organization receives plenty of new funding opportunities including COVID-related work
cons:
-Many managers overwork and bully their own staff as well as those in other units. Unless you luck out with a supportive manager, you are expected to be available for work at all hours. It is near impossible to enjoy vacation as it is frowned upon to actually be offline during days off and senior staff set a poor example by responding to emails at all hours even during their own vacation time. Some managers show no appreciation for the work their staff do, despite junior-level staff doing the majority of the work driving projects forward. 
-Little appreciation is given to country staff, especially when grant-related deadlines are set without any respect for time zone differences and competing priorities. ICAP should be working to decentralize the work from HQ and give more power to country teams to lead the projects in their own countries. There are too many people hired in NY to do jobs that should be handled locally.
-ICAP HQ refuses to push back on unreasonable requests from the funder and prides itself in "never saying no'' to funding, even if it is not in the best interest of the organization or staff.
-The majority of senior management at HQ are white, cis, straight people, and you can feel the impact of that trickle down. ICAP formed a Racism Taskforce in June 2020 and it is hard to tell if the taskforce has any actual power to enact change or if anything has in fact changed since then.
-After working remote for 16 months, the organization is forcing everyone back to the office at least 3 days per week. Currently everyone must wear masks for the full workday unless they have their own private office (senior management).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Great pay - The only thing keeping me going by the end. 
-Excellent benefits - Besides the standard benefits, some highlights include ability for you and your dependents (spouse, children) to study at Columbia for free, and contributions on your behalf to a retirement account, regardless of whether or not you make your own contributions 
-Work life balance achievable (with effort) - Many people don’t achieve it, but if you make the conscious choice that you won’t bleed yourself dry, you can close the laptop at 5.30 every day and go live your life
-The people - 95% of the people I worked with were amazing and inspiring and doing really good work.
cons:
Zero accountability - Consistent pattern of country teams ignoring requests for funder-required deliverables, or of turning in shoddy and frankly embarrassing work. When this happens, HQ staff are expected to polish a turd. It’s one thing to collaborate on things together to build off each other’s strengths and close weakness gaps; this is not that. Some teams have learned that there’s no consequences for this kind of behavior, so they run with it; can’t blame them. Every time this gets raised to management, employees are told to report it next time it happens, which they would, but nothing ever changed and the same cycle repeated time and time again. 

Overly prescriptive on the weirdest stuff, ignores the real issues - Staff will get guides with exact email language they should use to circulate a pdf, but no one seems to know who’s responsible for more major tasks like managing financials on certain projects. 

Overloaded portfolios - No one at the mid level can do the quality of work they’d like to do because they’re overworked and have no admin support 

Post-COVID measures show zero care for what employees want - It’s a widely known “secret” the founder doesn’t like remote work. Staff have been told not to ask about it, despite there being a Columbia policy allowing it. In post covid times, teams had hoped there would at least be a conversation about what returning to work looks like. Instead staff got an email with a top down diktat about how this would be managed (spoiler: it wasn’t sensitive to what people wanted, nor did it even ask employees what they wanted). Kicker is most staff are finding themselves commuting over an hour one way to sit in solo offices alone with their doors closed b/c of Columbia covid requirements, which they could frankly do from home without the stress or cost of a commute. A lot of people are leaving in response to this. When staff raised concerns about return to work and expressed a desire for a conversation about the new normal, they were shut down, which is quite on brand. There are far too many global health and global development orgs and companies out there doing things like employee surveys, and responding to what employees want, for them to be taking this approach. Frankly, people have options and they’re going to exercise them if this keeps up. 

No growth - No path for growth. If you look at the org chart, the mid level people with titles like “Senior Blah Blah Blah” are the bottom of the org chart, so they’re supposed to be Senior Blah Blah Blahs while also doing insane amounts of grunt and admin work. Past these roles, you get to a Deputy Director or Director, and there’s only a handful of these, so if you want to grow you have to go
